name: EOD Primary Tumor
title: EOD Primary Tumor
notes:
**Note 1:** If both eyes are involved, code the information for the most extensively involved eye in this field. 

**Note 2:** Pathological staging information from an enucleation always takes precedence over clinical staging, except in cases with neoadjuvant treatment where clinical disease is as extensive as or more extensive than disease at surgery.
footnotes:
(1) Fritz AG, Ries LAG (eds). **SEER Extent of Disease 1988: Codes and Coding Instructions (3rd Edition, 1998)**, National Cancer Institute, NIH Pub. No. 98-2313, Bethesda, MD, 1998

(2) Young JL Jr, Roffers SD, Ries LAG, Fritz AG, Hurlbut AA (eds.). **SEER Summary Staging Manual-2000: Codes and Coding Instructions**, National Cancer Institute, NIH Pub. No. 01-4969, Bethesda, MD, 2001.

(3) Collaborative Stage Work Group of the American Joint Committee on Cancer. **Collaborative Stage Data Collection System User Documentation and Coding Instructions, version 02.05**. American Joint Committee on Cancer (Chicago, IL)

(4) Gress, D.M., Edge, S.B., Gershenwald, J.E., et al. **Principles of Cancer Staging**. In: Amin, M.B., Edge, S.B., Greene, F.L., et al. (Eds.) AJCC Cancer Staging Manual. 8th Ed. New York: Springer; 2017: 3-30

(5) Mallipatna, A.C., Finger, P.T., et al. **Retinoblastoma**. In: Amin, M.B., Edge, S.B., Greene, F.L., et al. (Eds.) AJCC Cancer Staging Manual. 8th Ed. New York: Springer; 2017: 819-831
rows:
CLINICAL diagnosis only
Intraretinal tumor(s) with subretinal fluid
- Equal to but not greater than 3 millimeter (mm)
- AND Location not closer than 1.5 mm to optic disk or fovea

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Intraretinal tumor(s) with subretinal fluid
- Greater than 3 millimeter (mm)
- AND Location closer than 1.5 mm from disc or fovea

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Intraretinal tumor(s) with subretinal fluid ≤5 mm from the base of any tumor

Tumor confined to retina, NOS
Localized, NOS

PATHOLOGICAL diagnosis only
Intraocular tumor(s) WITHOUT any 
- Local invasion
- Focal choroidal invasion 
- Pre- or intralaminar involvement of the optic nerve head

Tumor confined to retina, NOS
Localized, NOS

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Intraocular tumor(s) WITH
- Subretinal fluid greater than 5 mm [0.5 cm] from base of tumor
- WITH or WITHOUT retinal detachment

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Intraocular tumor(s) WITH
- Vitreous seeding and/or subretinal seeding
- WITH or WITHOUT retinal detachment

PATHOLOGICAL diagnosis only
Intraocular tumor(s) WITH local invasion
- Concomitant focal choroidal invasion 
- AND pre- or intralaminar involvement of optic nerve head

PATHOLOGICAL diagnosis only
Intraocular tumor(s) WITH local invasion
Stromal invasion iris
- AND/OR trabecular meshwork 
- AND/OR Schlemm’s canal

CLINICAL or PATHOLOGICAL 
Intraocular tumor(s) WITH local invasion, NOS
Intraocular tumor(s) with retinal detachment, vitreous seeding, or subretinal seeding, NOS

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Advanced intraocular tumor(s) WITH
- Phthisis or pre-phthisis bulbi

PATHOLOGICAL diagnosis only
Intraocular tumor(s) WITH significant local invasion
- Massive choroidal invasion (greater than 3 mm [0.3 cm] in largest diameter)
- OR multiple foci or focal choroidal involvement (greater than 3 mm)
- OR full-thickness choroidal involvement

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Advanced intraocular tumor(s) WITH invasion of
- Anterior chamber
- Choroid
- Ciliary body
- Iris
- Lens
- Pars plana
- Zonules

PATHOLOGICAL diagnosis only
Intraocular tumor(s) WITH significant local invasion
- Retrolaminar invasion of optic nerve head
- NOT involving transected end of optic nerve

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Advanced intraocular tumor(s) WITH
- Raised intraocular pressure with neovascularization 
- AND/OR buphthalmos

PATHOLOGICAL diagnosis only
Intraocular tumor(s) WITH significant local invasion
- Any partial-thickness involvement of sclera within inner two thirds

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Advanced intraocular tumor(s) WITH
- Hyphema AND/OR massive vitreous hemorrhage

PATHOLOGICAL diagnosis only
Advanced intraocular tumor(s) WITH
- Full-thickness invasion into outer third of sclera 
- AND/OR invasion into or around emissary channels

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Advanced intraocular tumor(s) WITH
- Aseptic orbital cellulitis

CLINICAL OR PATHOLOGICAL 
Advanced intraocular tumor(s) WITH significant local invasion

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Extraocular tumor(s) involving orbit
- Radiologic evidence of retrobulbar optic nerve involvement 
- OR thickening of optic nerve and/or orbital tissues

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Extraocular tumor(s) involving orbit, including optic nerve
- WITH proptosis AND/OR an orbital mass

CLINICAL diagnosis only
Extraocular tumor(s) involving orbit, including optic nerve, NOS

PATHOLOGICAL diagnosis only
Evidence of extraocular tumor
- Tumor at transected end of optic nerve
- Tumor in the meningeal spaces around optic nerve

Full-thickness invasion of sclera WITH invasion of 
- Adjacent adipose tissue
- Bone
- Conjunctiva
- Episclera 
- Extraocular muscle
- Eyelids

Unknown; extension not stated
Primary tumor cannot be assessed
Not documented in patient record

Death Certificate Only
